course.subject: CENG
course.name: Biotechnology and Its Business Opportunities
course.description: This course gives an introductory overview of biotechnology from both technical and business perspectives. It surveys the current landscape of medical biotechnology, discusses the significant milestones in this field, describes underlying scientific concepts, and emphasizes the impact of innovations on human health and economy. Case studies are used to illustrate the opportunities and limitations in current and future biotechnology development. In addition, experts from industry and academia are invited to give guest lectures on course-related topics.

reviews.author: correctiontape

reviews.comment_content:
Interesting content for science students, especially those in BIOT ot BIBU.
The science content can be complicated for non-science students, but it doesnt matter as the final exam is open book.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Sun Fei is a nice professor who is passionate about biotechnology (His field of research), although his teaching can get boring sometimes as he reads off the powerpoint of some chapters, he tries his best to explain the concepts in between.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was wonderful for me, despite missing 50% of the morning lectures.
(Estimated studying time: 2-3 hours a week)
Letter grade: A+
However, this does not mean you are encouraged to skip lectures regularly.

Since I already had a decent foundation for biotechnology, the content was relatively lightweight for me. I highly encourage those without science background to pay attention during lectures for better understanding, as the concepts will come in the final exam.

The grade depends on both the presentation and final exam (open book), I have forgotten the exact weighting but dont take them lightly.

Final presentation involves a biotech business start-up idea, exact details may vary depending on the prof. My group used nicely designed slides and presented online in zoom.

Final exam is open-book, making it fair for all students from different majors. To get a good grade, make sure you understand the concepts first and apply them!!
Most answers can be done in a "blow-water" style, but make sure you are coherent and have applied the correct science/ business concept!!!

Overall, a fun course with a rewarding grading system. If you pay enough effort consistently, a B+ to A is highly attainable.
reviews.comment_workload:

I had 2 readings, a group business idea presentation and a final exam

reviews.comment_content:
This course gives an introductory overview of biotechnology from both technical and business perspectives. It surveys the current landscape of medical biotechnology, discusses the significant milestones in this field, describes underlying scientific concepts, and emphasizes the impact of innovations on human health and economy. Case studies are used to illustrate the opportunities and limitations in current and future biotechnology development. In addition, experts from industry and academia are invited to give guest lectures on course-related topics.
The course is divided into three main parts. Part I talks about the roots of biotechnology. The technological development of some classical biotechnology products is highlighted, in the context of the opportunities captured by the companies that are considered biotechnology giants nowadays in US. Part II presents the growth of supporting technologies and the emergence of new start-up companies. Part III discusses the key elements for building biotechnology companies and biotechnology clusters, with emphasis on the increasingly significant role of universities in technology transfer, and provides a glimpse of the biotechnology picture in China and the nearby regions.

As there are multiple attempts possible for the assignments, you can essentially reverse-engineer the answers to questions that are instantly graded. This will give you time to work on the extended response questions, which are obviously graded from a slightly subjective standpoint.
